name: Magnhild Lien
content:
Magnhild Lien is a Norwegian mathematician specializing in knot theory. She is a professor emeritus of mathematics at California State University, Northridge,[1][2] and the former executive director of the Association for Women in Mathematics.[3][4]
 Lien was born in Arendal, a town on the southern Norwegian island of Tromøya,[5] where she grew up as the youngest of six children and the only girl in her family.[3][4]
She earned a bachelor's degree from McGill University in 1979, and completed her Ph.D. in 1984 from the University of Iowa.[1] Her dissertation, Construction of High Dimensional Knot Groups from Classical Knot Groups, was supervised by Jonathan Kalman Simon.[6]
 She joined the faculty at California State University, Northridge in 1987,
and served as department chair of mathematics there from 1998 to 2006.[2]
She was executive director of the Association for Women in Mathematics from 2012 to 2018.[3][4]
 As well as publishing her own mathematical research on knot theory, Lien has written about women in mathematics in collaboration with her husband, sociologist Harvey Rich.[3]
 Lien was included in the 2019 class of fellows of the Association for Women in Mathematics "for extraordinary leadership and service devoted to advancing and supporting women in the mathematical sciences, as AWM executive director and, for a quarter century, as initiator, director, and fundraiser of programs for women".[7]
tags: Fellows of the Association for Women in Mathematics

raw:
Norwegian mathematician
Magnhild Lien is a Norwegian mathematician specializing in knot theory. She is a professor emeritus of mathematics at California State University, Northridge,[1][2] and the former executive director of the Association for Women in Mathematics.[3][4]

Contents

1 Education and career
2 Contributions
3 Recognition
4 References


Education and career[edit]
Lien was born in Arendal, a town on the southern Norwegian island of Tromøya,[5] where she grew up as the youngest of six children and the only girl in her family.[3][4]
She earned a bachelor's degree from McGill University in 1979, and completed her Ph.D. in 1984 from the University of Iowa.[1] Her dissertation, Construction of High Dimensional Knot Groups from Classical Knot Groups, was supervised by Jonathan Kalman Simon.[6]
She joined the faculty at California State University, Northridge in 1987,
and served as department chair of mathematics there from 1998 to 2006.[2]
She was executive director of the Association for Women in Mathematics from 2012 to 2018.[3][4]

Contributions[edit]
As well as publishing her own mathematical research on knot theory, Lien has written about women in mathematics in collaboration with her husband, sociologist Harvey Rich.[3]

Recognition[edit]
Lien was included in the 2019 class of fellows of the Association for Women in Mathematics "for extraordinary leadership and service devoted to advancing and supporting women in the mathematical sciences, as AWM executive director and, for a quarter century, as initiator, director, and fundraiser of programs for women".[7]

References[edit]


^ a b "Emeritus Faculty: Lien, Magnhild", University Catalog 2018–2019, California State University, Northridge, retrieved 2018-10-07

^ a b Emeriti Faculty, California State University, Northridge Faculty Senate, retrieved 2018-10-07

^ a b c d Lauter, Kristin (January–February 2018), "Tribute to Magnhild Lien" (PDF), AWM Newsletter, 48 (1): 4–5

^ a b c "CSUN Professor Named Exec. Dir. of Association for Women in Mathematics", CSUN Today, August 24, 2012

^ Onzol, Christie (July 8, 2010), When Flexibility is the Rule – Dr. Magnhild Lien: A Biographical Essay, Association for Women in Mathematics, retrieved 2019-01-26

^ Magnhild Lien at the Mathematics Genealogy Project

^ 2019 Class of AWM Fellows, Association for Women in Mathematics, retrieved 2019-01-26
